That's right, Sawan, it's not the first barrier. Now, let me see... That roadblock with the wall in the south of Cordon is the third. They started building it when the Zone first expanded. A lot of people died on the perimeter back then. Some got hit, but most got mauled by mutants. Nobody had ever seen such large numbers of those things, there were dozens or even hundreds of them! All the nearby units were alerted. Oh, what a massacre that was! Mortars, helicopters, tanks, APCs - everything was fired at once. There were even requests for bombardment sent over the radio, but by then everything had calmed down. After that incident, they began to take the Zone seriously. They decided not to rebuild the old barrier, and quickly built minefields in the south of the Dump. But they did not stop there either. They decided to build a second line of defence in case the first failed. The current roadblock to the south is the former second line. Now it's on the front line.

Why does the military roadblock look so weird? I mean, it doesn't look like a fortified defensive position. And this wall is weird, why is it built so that some of the structures are inside the perimeter?

A roadblock confuses you? It's not a roadblock. There weren't any military buildings here before. Before the accident in '86, there was a service station here. And even afterwards it was still used, refuelled and repaired the equipment that worked at Chernobyl. And after the emergence of the Zone the military settled down. No wall was even meant to be here at that time. They began to build it after the first breakthrough, when this roadblock was declared the second line of the Chernobyl Abnormal Zone barrier. But the engineers got it wrong in a hurry, or for some other reason, but they started building the wall to the south of the roadblock. After it had been built, all the buildings would have been inside the Zone. Someone at the time was kicked in the butt for their oversight, and they decided to turn the wall around, so that it would at least cover some of the buildings. And that's how it got so fucked up.
Where's the gate? I didn't see it there.

They're gone, torn down. Mutants went for a breach a couple of months ago. What's noteworthy is that it wasn't there that day. Just in a flash, hordes of dogs, wild boars and flesh-eaters appeared from somewhere in the north, tore down the gate, trampled a few soldiers, and moved on to the Big Land. And as the helicopters arrived and began to iron the mutants, something strange happened - all the creatures in a single rush turned around and raced back to the centre of the Zone. No one understood what it was, nothing like it had ever been seen before. They decided not to rebuild the gates, they would soon finish the second line anyway, and then the soldiers would be taken out of here. You're from the south, by the way, aren't you? Have you seen the second line? It's beautiful, isn't it? All the rules of fortification: flamethrowers, mortars, fortified trenches and pillboxes with redoubts. A minefield of sorts, no Turk could get through. They have poured billions of money into it. Europe has nothing to spare on security, the sponsorship is top-notch.
Thanks for the information!
Question 2
Answer 2
Thank you for the information!
Question 3
Answer 3
Thank you for the information!
Question 4
Answer 4
Thank you for the information!
Question 5
Answer 5
Thank you for the information!
Anything in particular you are interested in?
Tell me something interesting.
Have you heard the story about the American spies?
No, what's the story?

Well, listen. Last year, Skidan got an offer to organize a camping trip through the Zone for three foreigners. The money was good, so the salesman agreed. But he's a sneaky guy, checks everything out. In general, he ran through his channels information about these foreigners, and found out that they are not tourists, but the agents of the CIA. Skidan didn't want to lose the money, but he didn't want to set the stalkers up either.
So what did he do?

He came to me, explained everything to me. We had a heart-to-heart talk and found a solution - to send Ilya Muromsky as a guide. You know, the nickname is appropriate. The giant is over two meters tall, with a length of his shoulders and a tremendous amount of strength. He once snapped a boar's neck with his bare hands. So he can stand up for himself if anything happens.
And then?

At the appointed time Ilya met with the "tourists" and took them to the densest places of the border locations. The "tourists" wanted to see some mutants from afar, take pictures of them and, if they were lucky, even shoot some. But Ilya did not know English well enough to understand even a tenth of what his charges told him. The accumulated baggage of knowledge was enough only to understand that the guests want to beat the mutants, and Ilya decided to do it.
I think I'm beginning to guess.

Listen, this is only the beginning. For three days Ilya dragged the poor Americans with him. They had seen and seen what they had not seen during that time. In the dungeons of Agroproma, a bloodsucker attacked them and nearly killed one "tourist. Ilya "accidentally" forgot to warn the foreigners about zombies on Amber, and when one half-decayed corpse begins to rise on its feet in a meter from the spy going to the bathroom, the latter went to the bathroom right there. I do not speak about several packs of wild boars, blind dogs and carnivores, on which Ilyusha, again "accidentally", led the group. And on the third day, on the way back, Ilya proposed to spend the night in an unfinished complex in the north of the Dark Valley. Of course, he was silent about the Burer again. I do not even know who was more afraid that night - American spies, who saw so close the smelly and dirty midgets in tattered robes, or the Burer, who met the "tourists", shrieking with horror. When Ilya recounted it all, we nearly burst out laughing.\nBut that was not all. The next morning, the "tourists," with their trousers full of memories, returned to the Cordon to Skidan to get them across the roadblock. The post was lively that day - some bigwigs had arrived from abroad. Kolyazin asked Skidan to arrange special conditions for the new arrivals. The foreigners turned out to be three CIA agents, officially sent to the Zone to undergo a special training programme. Skidan was puzzled as to why the CIA would first send some of its agents as "tourists" and then officially send three more agents. He shared these thoughts with the "tourists", to which they explained with horror in broken Russian, which they had managed to learn during these three days with Ilyukha, that they were not spies at all, but usual tourists, they simply came to see the Zone and paid dear money for the vouchers. They had nothing to do with the CIA.
Holy shit! Does this mean that your Ilya Muromsky was dragging the real tourists around the Zone, scaring them in every possible way by thinking they were spies? You guys are unbelievable! Ha-ha-ha!
Yeah, that's the story. Almost got people killed. By the way, Ilyukha and I sent the official spies along the same route. The burers in the Dark Valley were so happy. Hehe!
Thank you, you cheered me up.
Thanks for the information!
Question 2
Answer 2
Thank you for the information!
Question 3
Answer 3
Thank you for the information!
Question 4
Answer 4
Thank you for the information!
Question 5
Answer 5
Thank you for the information!
Where are you from?
I was born in the glorious city of Okha on Sakhalin. I hope you know where it is. Because these days, young people aren't interested in anything, let alone their own country.
About Sakhalin? Of course I know, it's an island in the Far East, not far from Japan. Wow, where did you come from? What did you do there?

It's a working-class town, lives mostly off oil and gas. And there's a place for the old trades as well, logging and fishing. So there was always plenty of work. But ever since childhood I had an urge for adventure, I could not sit still in one place. I had to explore all the mountains and forests around me. But that wasn't enough for me. So as soon as I turned eighteen, I was happy to go to the enlistment office. In my case, it was the only way to get off the island and see the world.
Thanks for the information!
How did you get into the Zone?

I still do not know whether it was a chain of coincidences or the Zone itself brought me here. In general, I proved myself well in the army. I have been good at sports since I was a baby, so even two years in the Special Forces was not too much for me. Although I did manage to get through the Afghan war, I was lucky not to take part in fights. Then, on the recommendation of the headquarters, I was sent to military training. While I was studying, I started a family. I did not have any children, but it turned out to be for the best. After graduation I was dragged around the garrisons, I had no time for children. Then I was sent to Chechnya. That's where I lost my Marishka... Why the fool did I take her with me, they said it was dangerous at the base, Dudayev's guerrillas could attack. And I... idiot... I didn't keep it safe.
Sorry, I didn't mean to remind you... Sorry, I didn't know.

Forget it, it's my fault, my past, my cross. I have to live with it till the day I die. Maybe that's why the Zone brought me in, don't you think? There was a lot more after the first Chechen war, I can't tell you everything. But I remember the appearance of the Zone like I remember it now. It's impossible to forget such a commotion. In the first hours no one even knew what had happened: a reactor exploded or a meteorite fell, or maybe a war had broken out. In Moscow there was no less excitement than in Kiev. Then our troops were sent to the Zone, as agreed. I'll never forget that day, the Zone did its best. I lost almost my entire squad because of the staff rats. They had to find out how anomalies affect people. Bastards. And no one even asked us. How Sergey, Dimka and I got out of there, I have no idea. It was like the Zone itself was leading us between the anomalies. As soon as I got into the headquarters, I shot the general between the eyes. I was about to take my gun out of my holster, but I got caught. I would have been in jail for a long time if it hadn't been for my friends who helped me out of the cell. After I left the camp, I had no choice: either try to survive in the Zone, or try to exist outside the Zone. So I chose my own path - it's better to live a little in the Zone than to exist for the rest of my life in prison.
Yeah, that's the story. Don't you long for home, for your homeland?

You know, at first I didn't feel it at all, I didn't have time for it. Now the Zone is more or less settled, everywhere you go you're bound to run into someone. But back then there was no one here at all. Even though I'm a combat officer, I've seen enough horrors while in the service, but when you watch the well-known laws of physics being broken and see your true comrade vanishing in agony right in the air, you've got no sense of self-control, fear replaces all the feelings. But you can't lose your knack, so somehow I managed to survive. Then, over time, when I gained experience in the Zone, thoughts of the future began to arise. Now I really want to go home. To see my parents, if they're still alive. To see my hometowns. Believe me, I'd even be ready to go to court if they'd let me spend at least a day in my homeland. Ah...
Thanks for the information!
Question 3
Answer 3
Thank you for the information!
Question 4
Answer 4
Thank you for the information!
I have already told you everything I know.
Question 5
Answer 5
Thank you for the information!
No, I changed my mind.
text in default
That's it, you fella, dry your paddle.
What's going on?! Why is everyone hitting me on the head?!
You're lucky to be alive. I guess the Speech Therapist has plans for you. Heh-heh.
My head hurts so bad. Listen, bro, why don't we make a deal? I can pay you.
What are you gonna pay me? You ain't got nothing! And I don't want to deal with the speech therapist later. I don't want that kind of trouble.
My partner's got money. He'll pay! Whatever you say, he'll pay. His name is Borland.
Borland, you say? It's a familiar name. I've heard of him. A stalker in authority. This one might pay. Well, you stay here and think about your sins, and I'll talk to your mate. Don't go anywhere.
I can't get out of the cage.
Ugh! You scared the hell out of me! What the hell are you doing here?
Skidan?! What a meeting! What are you doing here?
Shroud, come clean. I can see right through you, you can't hide anything from me. Borland will tell you that.
We... we're... kind of...
Just tell it like it is, don't pull your balls out.
Did you hear about the Liberty stalker case?

The suicide case? Of course I heard about it, but the whole Cordon is worried about the Libertines coming here to investigate. Can't really prove to them he shot himself. You're the only witness. So what's wrong with this stalker?
He wasn't a free man. He was an undercover agent for the Monolith.

Oh, really?! No way. Are you drunk or something? Monolith, heh. That's a hell of a thing to say. Where'd that come from? Their faction's long gone, their puppeteers all dead. There's no Monolith, not anymore.
What are you talking about? What puppeteers?
I'll tell you later. It's a long story. You tell me about the agent first. You didn't bring him up for nothing, did you?

Well, the monolith had a PDA on him, but it was locked. I asked Stjepka to unlock it. That's when I came to you for the walkie-talkie. When I came back from your place, I went to Stoepka's booth and he was gone. I went looking for him... and I found him. I wish you hadn't.
None of your damn business. That's the third time this week they've broken the alarm. Where do you get off being so smart?
So? Don't drag it out, tell me.
Stoepka was killed.
So that's where he disappeared. And the whole camp has been looking for him for 24 hours. Why didn't you say anything before?

Wait, Skidan, let me finish. When I was leaning over Stoepka, someone hit me in the head. I was unconscious on the elevator for hours. When I woke up, Stoepka was as dead as if he hadn't been there. And who would believe me that I didn't kill him if there wasn't even a body?
Well, you got that right. Wait a minute, where did you say you found Stjepka, at the grain elevator?
Yes, yesterday. Why? Do you have any idea who might have knocked me out?

Yes, but I can't tell you. All I can tell you is that yesterday I arranged a meeting for very serious people at the grain elevator, and that meeting fell through. Apparently, because of you and Stjepka. But who could kill the technician remains a mystery to me. Although...
What? Skidan, come on. Stupeka's been murdered, it's not about privacy.

All right, all right, this is serious. I sent a stalker to the grain elevator. He found an interesting container on the Dump the other day, which my clients from the centre of the Zone have been looking for. It was their money that Shmyga stole.
What kind of container? What's inside? And who's the stalker?
Skidan, what alarm? What's the third time this week? It's our first time here, honest to God.

Who the hell knows what's inside the container. I didn't open it, just looked at the numbers on the lid and knew right away it was the container my clients were looking for. The stalker's name was Dubolom. He was delighted when I told him about the deal. I didn't dare buy the container back from him myself, so I arranged a meeting. But now I don't know what happened there - the clients didn't get the container, the stalker disappeared, and you and Stoepka. My clients couldn't have attacked Stoepka - it's not their style. And I don't think the stalker would dare do that, either. I can't vouch for him, though. That leaves someone else. Bandits, maybe?

A douche bag? Oh, wow! I know him, Wolf asked me to find this stalker the first time we met. He seemed strange to me even then, he obviously didn't care about his loot. But he's up to no good. Maybe he killed Stoepka. And then hit me over the head as a witness?
Maybe he did, though he seemed like a normal guy. Why would he kill Stoepka? I don't know. That's a really strange story. And I don't know where to find Dubololok now, either.

Yes, that's it... Where was I? Oh yes, I remember. I found an unlocked monolith's PDA at Stjepka's place. There were only a few recent messages on it. Briefly, it spoke about some group of stalkers, who stole an artifact from the monoliths, and they chased them. The artifact had destructive influence on people, it was said something about psyche, too abstruse. That is why they put it in a container, and the stalkers stole this container from the monoliths.
Container, you say? Isn't that the container...?

Maybe it is. Anyway, listen to me. During the chase, some stalkers were killed, but the rest managed to get lost. So the monoliths brought in their undercover agents to find the kidnappers. I don't know how many of these agents there were, but an undercover agent got here to Cordon. He tracked one of the stalkers to a rookie village, but the bandits got him. I don't know why they had to do that.

I don't get it. So, what, so Dubolom is one of those stalkers? That can't be right. He's only been in the Zone for a couple of weeks, he only went to the Dump the other day, stayed there for a day, and then came back. The same day he brought me that container. I told you what happened next.

So Dubolomk found this container at the Dump. Most likely, the stalkers who stole the artifact hid it at the Salvage, and Dubolom accidentally stumbled upon it. He couldn't have killed them. Or could he? I mean, somebody killed Stupid. And then there's the artifact. What do you think the artifact is in the container, Skidan?

Who knows? Artifacts pop up every day. But come to think of it, I do recall one artifact with a similar effect. It's called a pendulum. Only it's an extremely rare artifact, only two have ever been found. It's worth a lot of money.
What's it worth so much?

Stop telling me that! Who else could have snagged the alarm? It's designed for humans, not to be activated by a marmot or a dog. Which means only a human could have stepped on that tripwire. And if not you, then who?

This artifact is double-edged. On the one hand, it absorbs all psi radiation, and on the other, it radiates it with incredible power. The poles of absorption and emission change, with each other over a period of time, after an hour or so. That's why it has to be flipped constantly if you carry it on your belt.\nThis artefact was first found by Broker's group. The properties of the Pendulum weren't immediately clear to them, so only Corkscrew made it to the science camp on Amber alive. He could hardly stand on his feet. The botanists took him by helicopter to the Great Land, but naturally, they kept the artifact for themselves to study. Several of their own lab assistants almost died while they were trying to put together a suitable protective container. I learned this later, from a copy of the report. Sakharov slipped it to me. Since then nothing is known about the first artifact. They're probably still studying it in some secret research institute.\
What about the second one?
Oh, there's a much more interesting story. You ever heard of the Strelka?
No, I haven't heard of him. What's the shooter?

Oh, brother, he's not a stalker, he's a legend! I don't know when he appeared in the Zone, but he knew his job by heart - sometimes he brought such artifacts that you could not believe it. And where he found them, no one still understands. One day he was lucky enough to find the Pendulum. He was a clever fellow, and as soon as he felt bad he immediately understood that the artifact had a negative influence. I do not know how many days he studied the artifact, but he found out almost the same thing about it as scientists in their labs did. And that in the field, can you imagine?! After that, he started dragging that artifact around. It's also how he got his group through the Brain Burner. They brought back so much stuff, there'd be enough loot for a small island in the Pacific. Merchants from all over the Zone almost lined up for artifacts, but he was stubborn, sold a few of them, and left the rest for himself or something else to do. Ah, he was a good man.
Why was he? What happened to him?

Couple years ago, Shooter suddenly disappeared. At the time, we thought he'd died from a massive explosion. I've never seen anything like this before. And believe me, I've seen a lot around here. But a few months later, Strelok was found alive in one of the death trucks. No one knows how he got there. He didn't remember anything himself, not even his name. I didn't recognise him at first - he was scary to look at: skinny, bruised, weathered face, unidentifiable scars all over his body. And there was this mark on his arm, as if he had been branded by beasts - a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. tattoo. But the strangest thing is that his PDA only had one entry to Kill Strelok. That's himself, can you imagine?
And then what?

I don't hide it. The Swordsman, Sidorovich called him for his tattoo, had his own agenda. He had to find Strelok, so he could probably find his hiding place too. But the most interesting thing for us was the way to the north of the Zone, because there is a Klondike of artifacts. Well, Sidorovich and the other dealers decided to use the Swordsman for dark purposes.
I'm not surprised.
Skidan, honestly, we didn't mean for any of this to happen. We agreed with the Watcher that he'd let us see the tunnel and the catacombs. We didn't mean anything by it.

Ahem. So the Gunslinger, that is, the Swordsman, set out in search of himself. So he followed his own footsteps to the North of the Zone. The scientists helped him with a prototype of a psi-blocker, so his brains wouldn't boil. In return, the Swordsman, unknowingly, gathered all the information for them about the inaccessible parts of the Zone. At the same time and two emitters turned off: one at the lake Amber, the other on Radar - the very same brain burner. The way to Pripyat and the centre of the Zone was open. Shouldn't have done that, but who knew how it would turn out.\nEveryone in the Zone went crazy. Only the laziest went to the centre. Everyone wanted to get to the grantor first. I then rejoiced, I thought that the way to the Pripyat and Chernobyl NPP open, now artifacts to me like a river flow. But there was no way out - no one came back. We took a loan of equipment and headed for Sarcophagus. And as soon as they reached Pripyat, the majority were killed there - the entire city was simply crawling with monoliths. And the factions with their own principles unleashed the war again - no one wanted to retreat, all just wanted to go forward. Later on, the military also joined in. In general, such a ruckus began. And in the end there was a blowout. I can't count the number of people killed.
And the shooter? Did he make it?

I don't know. No one's seen him since the incident. Couldn't even find a psi-locker with a transmitter, even though it had a GPS module. The blowout must have damaged it. The last coordinates indicated the entrance to the Sarcophagus, which means that the gunman had reached it a couple of minutes before he got there. He may have survived, but we'll never know. It's been a year since then, a lot of people have been in the centre. In one of the bunkers near Chernobyl some strange laboratory was found - there were corpses in capsules. It was as if they had been shot in their sleep. The stalkers found a lot of documents - they gave them all to the scientists. And it said so much that no one believed it. It was beyond belief.
What did it say?

There was technical information about psi emitters, generators and the wishbone. Turns out the Monolith was an artificial object, used to brainwash fanatics. This explained the fact that no one found the Wish Executor afterwards - there was nothing but a destroyed reactor in the Sarcophagus. Using this device some scientists from the O-Consciousness Project, as they called themselves in documents, hypnotized stalkers who got too close to the mystery of the emergence of the Zone. Recruited agents were given hidden tasks and sent to the borders of the Zone. Apparently Shooter somehow became one of these agents and was tasked to kill himself. But then the Monolith was destroyed. Monolith fanatics began to let go - a few dozen squads from the centre back, do not remember anything. They were almost killed here at first, because they were former enemies. But it turns out that not everyone has recovered from the hypnosis. Judging by your story there are a lot of puppets without puppeteers. And they are up to something, they did not put the Pendulum in the container for nothing. I wonder if that's the same artifact that belonged to Shooter.

You should be writing books, Skidan. You'd be famous in a heartbeat and get all the writing prizes. I feel like I'm hearing a novel in your retelling. All the laws of the genre: Prologue - plot - climax - denouement. Is that really how it happened? I can't even believe it. The Zone is full of wonders. We'll look around a bit, see if we can find anything interesting. Do you mind?

Hang on, Savannah. There's a case. In light of these events, I propose we make a deal: I'll outfit you with first-class weapons at my expense, and you find the Pendulum and sell it to me, and I'll pay good money. I'll even pay you more than it's worth. What do you say?
I don't know, Skidan. What if we don't find anything? What if it's just a stalker story? A legend and nothing more.
Well, then you'll get it all back and pay the minimum rent for your gear. The main thing is to stay alive, or else we'll look for you and take the armour off the corpses. It's not gonna be pretty.
Thanks, that's reassuring. We need to think it over. Come on, we'll come back later, okay? In the meantime, we'll wander around, maybe we'll find the Oakleys.
Wait a minute, so the Watcher let you in? You mean you didn't come in through the chimney?
What pipe? We took the stairs. What's a chimney?

Well, that's a nasty one, isn't it? You may act like a fool sometimes, Savannah, but you can't lie. Which means there's been three break-ins in the last week, not counting you. So what did you say you were looking for here?
I didn't say we were looking for anything. Come on, Skidan. We just wanted to see what's going on, that's all.\
I've thought about your offer. We're in. We'll bring you the artifact. Give me your cool guns and armor. I also need a code and a key card to get into the underground lab under the Cordon.

Now, that's another conversation. Now, here's where I've got it stashed. There you go! Just as I told you, it's not the hottest piece of equipment in the Zone, but it has been proven in many walks. You can only get it on order from the Big Land. Or on the Bar, if you're lucky. Give me your PDA, I'll text you the master code. It's better than any key card. It's a hundred percent good, unlike the usual service ciphers. I'll know the password any minute, and I'll radio it to you on your PDA. Here's the ammunition, as promised. I've already provided Borland with armor and weapons and he's waiting for you downstairs. I'm about to open my private secret passage to the catacombs for you. All right, ready?
I'm ready.
Tell me about yourself.

Independence is something I value very much, because I've always been on my own and only worked for myself. But when I heard the stalkers were squeezing out the military and setting up their base, I came straight here. I, you know, have crossed paths with many people in the Zone, but as far as I'm concerned, stalkers are the best. Well, how can I put it... they're normal, you know? Without all that stupid stuff with codes and rules, like in other factions. In the long run, the only people in the Zone should be stalkers: then there'd be mutual assistance everywhere, and it'd be quieter. So I decided to support these guys.
It's rare to meet a technician in the Zone. Tell me, what can you do?

Well, don't expect any fancy gadgets or fancy stuff from me. But don't hold your breath, either: I've got a pot that still works, and I've got my hands in the right place.\nAnything that could save your life, I'm good at it. Repairing most weapons and armour, and if the necessary parts turn up, I may even be able to improve your gun or armour. If you want to know what I do, take a look at the Upgrades, I think you'll find it easy to figure out.
I take it you've been around the Zone a while? Seen anything unusual?

Unusual? I was coming here through Agroprom just after that powerful one. I looked - well, wonders... There's a patch of mangled earth in the old place where there wasn't a damn thing before. And it's so phoned up that you have to run past it. Then the guys told me that this anomaly is the most powerful: the energy comes out not just as a fountain, but as Niagara Falls! The place is the most dangerous, but the trick is that the rarest artifacts happen there most often. So if you come across this place, keep an eye out.
Tell me about yourself.

I'm a trader... a beginner. As you can see, we've only been here a short while. As soon as the Shaman told me everyone could be anything they wanted, I decided I'd be a merchant and no nails. Why, I've got skills, and Skidan's right there, a living example... If you want to know, back in high school I had an electronic toy - you know, the dog used to catch chicken eggs? - I used to sell this thing to my classmates for ten kopecks a batch. I've got that vein, you know? Yeah, those were the golden days... Now I'm getting the hang of it, getting into the trade, so to speak. I'm taking Skidan's merchandise for sale, so the prices, you know, aren't great yet. But there's something interesting to be found: the guys have already started bringing me their stuff.

Oh, man, we're gonna live like Christ in the palm of our hands... or whoever's in charge of us sinners. The soldiers won't be oppressing us any more, now everything will go for the stalker's benefit. And after the raid will be able to rest on Cordon, and the equipment will appear... For the loot will also get real money, not like before: the scraps for us, and the cream for the military. Wait, we'll have another go at the warriors! Why? They can't relax, you know, they're not in a fairy tale! In a word, let's get on with it.
Do you think life will change on Cordon?

Oh, mate, we're going to live like we're in God's good graces now... or whoever's in charge of us sinners. The soldiers won't be oppressing us any more, now everything will be for the stalker's benefit. And after the raid will be able to rest on Cordon, and the equipment will appear... For the loot will also get real money, not like before: the scraps for us, and the cream for the military. Wait, we'll have another go at the warriors! Why? They can't relax, you know, they're not in a fairy tale! In a word, let's get on with it.
Thank you very much, comrade stalker.
You're welcome, comrade. Where do they send you to the Zone from?
I'm from Novosibirsk. You know, in Akademgorodok...
What's going on?! Why are you telling me this? It was a rhetorical question. That's it, I've done my job, let the others suffer with you now. Good luck!
Hey, Student. Shall we go?

Good day to you, sir! So you'll be my escort? Pleased to meet you. Are you an experienced stalker? Isn't it dangerous? Won't the bandits shoot us on the way? What about mutants? I hear there's a lot of mutants out there.
First of all, we're all on a first-name basis here. Secondly, we go quickly and silently. I emphasize silent! Thirdly, I'm a very experienced stalker, and I'll be fine. Let's go!
Are you the new mechanic?
Yes, Stjepka disappeared somewhere, now I'm in his place.
I wanted to know about the tools.
About what?
Well, I was bringing Stoepka some tools...
Yes, well, not all of them are still needed, if you find them, bring them.
Okay.
I brought you the tools.
Oh, great! What kind do you want to share?
For the rough stuff.
Oh, that's great! Now if I could just get some more tools for fine work and calibration...
Fine work.
Great! Now if I could just get some more tools for rough work and calibration...
For calibration.
Oh, that's great! Now if I could just get some more tools for the rough work and the fine work...
So far, none.
Oh, great! If I could get some more calibration tools, I'd be all set.
Cool! I wish I had some more tools to do the fine work and I'd be all right.
Oh, great! I wish I had some more tools for the rough stuff, and I'd be all right.
Wow! Well, that's... Where'd you find those?
If tools are the problem, I can get them.

That'd be great! I'm working like in the Stone Age. Only soldering iron from the new age, and that's more like a shaman's rod... If I have the tools, I'll have first-rate tunes. And you'll get a penny or two.
All right. I'll look for something.
I changed my mind.
Come on, it's a good subject. I get to make tunes, you get to make money.
Hi. Need any tools?
You're asking! Of course I do. Show me what you got.
For rough work.
Oh, that's great! Now I can modify your weapons and armour.
For fine work.
Great! Now our local science and technology progress will take a leap forward.
For calibration.
Great! Now I can make you such an automaton... such that Sidorovich would give you his soul for it, hehe.
Haven't found any tools yet. I'll keep looking.
Heh-heh. Welcome to our humble corner of happiness, sir. You're welcome to see our price list.
Huh?

Oh, man! You're quite a magician, aren't you? What's his name? Kupperfield! I respect that. All right, you can go through the tunnel one or two times. Me and my buddies will take care of the healing. The way's open, you can go wherever you need to go.
Already gone.
What's up? Give me the money, that's what!
Uh, I ain't got no money.

Heh-heh. You're funny. Where do you think you're going without the money, fool? No dough, no gear. No gear, no art. And no art... What's next? It was kinda nice... Oh, no art, no dough. Oh, yeah! It's called a vicious circle. You got it? Heh-heh. So why don't you get out of here while you're still in one piece? You'll thank me later. Look at you, a superhero. Heh-heh.
Guys, I gotta get to the other side. I really do. Why don't we make a deal?
He needs it. You never know who needs what. Maybe I need a hangover. Well, I'm not bothering you with my problems. Get out while you still can.
Well, why don't you get some vodka? I got some.
Guys, it's my first day in the Zone. Why don't you let me pass?
Heh-heh! Well, that's quite a turn-up, isn't it? Not even cats are born for that! So it's pay or get out - there's no third way!
Well, the hell with you.
You seem like a nice kid. Give me your vodka. But I won't let you in anyway. Heh-heh! And you thought you were in a fairy tale? Get out of here while I'm nice.
And I've got another bottle. Here you go.
Thank you. Mutants have been going crazy lately, giving me a hard time.
You're welcome, Granddad. You're the Watcher, aren't you?
You didn't live under the Soviet Union. They used to do things like turn back rivers. Oh, yeah! And digging holes in the ground was a piece of cake.
Grandpa, how do you get there, in those catacombs? I really want to see it.
You're so quick. Why should I let you into the tunnel? My superiors strictly told me not to let anyone in without my knowledge.
Grandpa, what bosses? There hasn't been a Zone here for a long time - there's no boss left.
What do you mean, gone? Who's making noise there?
Where?
In the tunnel. There's a noise every night. If it's not the bosses, who is it?
You never know. Creatures, mutants. Do you want to see?
You're trying to trick me, aren't you? All right. I kind of owe you one. All right, here's a spare key to my place. Just don't touch anything in the house!
All right, Grandpa. Thank you.
Yeah. Who are you?
They call me Savan. I was just looking for you.
Me? Wow. What can I do for you?
Tell me about the tunnel under the village.

Oh, boy. I see you're a straight shooter. You don't beat around the bush, you're a straight shooter. Well, I respect a straight shooter. All right, I'll tell it to you straight. But, you know, not a word to anyone, all right?
Grave!

After the Great Patriotic War, the Soviet leadership was extremely concerned about protective measures and escape routes for high-ranking officials. Therefore it was decided to create a secret extensive underground communication network. First and foremost, the network was to provide emergency evacuation from besieged cities such as Kiev, Minsk and Moscow. One of the underground railroad branches of this network is located here, under the Zone, which is the Kiev-Minsk route. Along with this branch, underground communications were built to service rolling stock, as well as to deliver materials to other important objects, which at the time were in short supply everywhere. And I was assigned to guard the back door. I've been guarding it ever since.
You mean the tunnel under the village leads to the railway? It can't be!
Oh, you're here! What more do you want?
Grandpa, what's wrong? Why are you so angry?
Son, find the bastard who went through my wardrobes without asking, I beg you. People have no shame and no conscience. And give me back my key.
I'll do anything, Grandpa, don't worry.
He's also mocking me. Why were you messing around in my house? What were you looking for? Money, valuables? I ain't got nothing but a watch, and that ain't even working.
Grandpa, come on, I wasn't looking for anything! I have nothing else to do.
And who's been going through my cupboards? The ghost? They also stole the map.
What card?
The access card. A key, to put it simply.
Not the door to the underground lab, is it?
How'd you know that? You definitely took it. Give it back!
What a coincidence, and I was just about to ask you for that key. I don't have the map, Grandpa. But I think I know who might have stolen it from you. Well, we'll have to go to the merchant for help.
What's there to see around here?

This place is for newcomers. There's a trader on the outskirts of the village called Skidanem. There's a military roadblock on the other side. That's where you came from. On the other side of the roadblock is the road deep into the Zone.
Tell me about the Rookie Village.

What can I tell you about this place? All who are more elegant, procured from Skidan the most necessary and move to the dump: there and artifacts thicker, and not as dangerous as closer to the centre of the Zone. One can gain experience. Although it is also possible to die in a jiffy: mutants, bandits, anomalies - there is an abundance of it all. Like everywhere else, more risk, more profit. And the only ones left here are complete... dickheads, to put it mildly. Sometimes such a miracle comes along - almost in slippers and with a handbag. He wanted romance, you know! Or some docent who's never held anything more serious than a slide rule. Such guys get screwed up fast, that's for sure. Sometimes veteran stalkers drop in to drop some loot for Skidan after a long way out, listen to the gossip from the Big Land, and have a rest for a day or two in a quiet place. It's not often, it's been a long time since anyone from the north came.
It's a nice place you got here. Just a resort. Doesn't the military bother you?

The military don't press, they don't have time for us now. They say there's no use wasting ammunition on those stalkers, they can die in anomalies anyway. And we, in response, don't get too cocky: if they're looking for someone, we don't get in the way - when there's a raid or a checkpoint from the HQ, we shelter in basements. In general, you can see for yourself that we're quiet and non-conflictual people.
Tell me about Skidan.

He's stingy, like all traders. Been trading on Cordon for years. His main customers are rookie stalkers new to the Zone. He has many connections, including contacts with the military, various factions in the Zone, and even bandits. The military smuggles his goods across the roadblock. That's the business. Rumor has it that he's been into trade since childhood, when he was a student he sold weak drugs illegally. Maybe not weak drugs. And kind of got in trouble with the penal code for it. I don't know if that's true or not. You can't believe every word of it, you know. Stalkers make up gossip, like old grannies on a bench outside the door. Almost all the stalkers in the Zone worked for Skidan in the beginning, so he knows about everyone, and has an opinion on everyone. In short, every dog in the Zone knows him!
Tell me about yourself.

I'm kind of in charge of this village. Kind of like a mentor to the newbies. I'm teaching the green stuff, the greenhouse goggles, so they don't get pinched on the first go-round by the bony one. Oh, it's hard to teach! Some are unlearnable in principle. You look at one and you think: What can you teach him?! He's read two books in his life - an ABC book and this blue one. And it's logical that they die in the first anomaly, forgetting to throw a nut in front of them. I've already tramped through the Zone myself, I've left a piece of my life here. I think I can get out of here, how much longer can I go on. Only an evil witch or some hex, no otherwise, and I can not get out in any way: either the soldiers with the raid, or over there blowout blows. And the money, frankly... sometimes there's a lucrative job offer, so why not take it? You know how it is, you think you're gonna make that last exit, and then I'm out, and then it's just like that over and over again.
Tell me about this place.
Tell me about this place.
Tell me about this place.

We're at Kordon now. To the south, beyond the army roadblock, is the outside world, and further north is the Zone. There is little reminiscent of it: anomalies are few, almost no artifacts, and the monsters are rare. There is not much noise here, too, because the military are trying to keep everything under strict control. In general, the place is quite quiet - of course, compared to the rest of the Zone.

We're at Cordon now. Beyond the army roadblock is the outside world, and further north is the Zone. There is little reminiscent of it: anomalies are few, almost no artifacts, and the monsters are rare. There is not much noise here, too, because the military are trying to keep everything under strict control. In general, the place is quite quiet - of course, compared to the rest of the Zone.

We're at Cordon now. Beyond the army roadblock is the outside world, and further north is the Zone. There is little reminiscent of it: anomalies are few, almost no artifacts, and the monsters are rare. There is not much noise here, too, because the military are trying to keep everything under strict control. In general, the place is rather quiet - of course, compared to the rest of the Zone.

This is the Rookie Village. On the outskirts is the bunker of Skidan, the merchant. Farther along is a military roadblock - that's actually where you came from. The other side of the roadblock is the road deep into the Zone.

This is the Rookie Village. At the edge is the bunker of Skidan, the merchant. Next is a military roadblock - that's where you came from. The other side of the roadblock is the road deep into the Zone.

This is the Rookie Village. At the edge is the bunker of Skidan, the merchant. Next is a military roadblock - that's where you came from. The other side of the roadblock is the road deep into the Zone.
Wolf, I thought about your offer and decided to sell you that artifact.
Good call. Skidan would have given you half as much for it. I know that cheapskate.
Yeah, well, I've seen it firsthand myself.
What's the job?

It's a dusty job, a passenger to the stalker camp at the ATP. Client's new to the Zone, but he's well provided for. Pays 10 grand. Half now, the rest on completion, if you bring him in alive. Mind you, he can't shoot. Don't expect any help on the road. Will you do it?
It's a deal. Where's your passenger?
He's over there, calling himself Student. When you get to the base, come back and I'll give you the second part of the money. Student will let me know when you get to the ATP.
All right, let's go.
No, Wolf, I'm sorry. I don't do deliveries. I'm a conductor like you're a ballerina. Maybe someone else can do it.
Suit yourself. That kind of money is hard to come by. And I'll always find someone willing. I thought of you first, I know you needed the money in a hurry. No, I don't.
Good luck.
I've been thinking... Anyway, I'm willing to take that rookie to ATP.
I don't know about that. All right, there he is, call him Student. When you get to ATP, come back to me, I'll give you the other part. Student will let me know how he gets to ATP.
Don't worry, Wolf, I'll do it right. It's only a short walk.
Too late, Savan, too late. The rookie's already gone. You're not the only stalker in the Zone, there are others who want to make money. Dutyo thought he'd missed out on a free job.
Didn't really feel like it.
Job done. A student at the TSA.
So, everything okay? Nothing happened on the road?
There was... A student happened. Oh, he's such a big mouth. Couldn't stop myself from shooting him. I can see why it's a high-paying job.
Yeah, he likes to talk. He's a nerd, for crying out loud. Speaking of pay, here's the second part, as promised.
All right, Wolf. Anything else comes up, let me know.
Got your message. What's your pleasure?

I will, I will. Found you a teacher. Give me your PDA, I'll drop you a tag on a stalker. His name is Leshim. He's a hunter. Not just a hunter, but a real legend of the Zone. You could say he ate a bloodsucker in this business.
What's in it for me? I'm not going to eat a bloodsucker.
You don't know how lucky you are, Savannah. The woodsman can teach you which mutant is the best to kill. Not every rookie gets that chance. He just needs a partner right now, so I thought of you.
Tag him.
I texted you the tag. Leschii will be waiting for you out by the road, near the ATP.
Thanks, Wolf.
Got your message. What kind of help do you need?
Good of you to come. I could've done it myself, but it'd be more fun with you. It'll teach you something, too.
What can I help you with?
Well, I got myself a new detector. I want to test it out in the field, so to speak. Let's go look for artifacts.
Afrikatos? Where would you look?

Anomalies. More specifically, anomalous fields. And not Afrikata. Artifacts. In short, artifacts. The backbone of the entire stalker trade. And the source of money. Shall I teach you how to collect artifacts?
You ask!
Well, then follow me. It's just around the corner.
Lead the way.
Come on, tell me what kind of art you got.
There!

Well, lucky you. You don't find many artifacts like this around here. You're a capable student. You've never been a stalker before? You sure about that? Just kidding.\nIf you want, I can buy that art from you for good money. Merchants will never give you full price, you know. I need that kind of art for a custom job. I can buy other art from you, but only rare ones. Think about it. If anything, you know where to find me.\nAll right, let's get to camp. You sure you can't wait around the campfire to tell the boys what you found?
Bragging ain't my style. If I find these artifacts, I'll bring them to you to sell. You know how much money you need.

All right, I found a path to the centre of the field. Detector says there's an artifact here. There's more than one. Now it's your turn. Here, I got you an upgrade, the bear detector. It not only shows you the distance to the artifact, but also the direction you're looking. Throw the bolts and go around the anomalies. When you see a signal on the screen, go in the same direction. Just be careful! You won't see the artifact right away. You have to get close to it first, that's when it will pop out of the anomaly field. Good luck!
Don't mention it!

Here we are. See that hole behind me? That's the anomalous field. You have to be very careful here. Any wrong move and you're a dead man. There's radiation and lots of gravitational anomalies. All right, here's what we're going to do: I'm going to survey the anomaly and find a passageway, and I'm going to test the detector. Meanwhile, you carefully watch my actions, but do not forget to watch out for mutants. You ready?
Yeah.
Hey, Wolf. Do you happen to know where I can find the Watcher? He's not at home, the door's locked, and I have a question for him.
Well, he's gone. The day before yesterday.
How far is he gone?
To the marshes. He collects some herbs there, and then makes tinctures. It's good for colds, I tell you. And for other ailments, too. And just to warm the soul.
Oh, man. He'll be back soon, didn't he say?

Yeah, he'll be back today. How long has it been? Hmm, he should be here by now. Strange, he's never late, they don't call him the Watcher for nothing. Maybe something's wrong? Listen, Sawan, you've got a job to do. Run to the tunnel near the military roadblock. That's the tunnel the Sentinel's supposed to use to get back from the Swamp. You never know what's going on down there. He's an experienced man, all his life in the Zone, but age takes its toll. I texted you the coordinates. That's it, let's go!
You're already there.
Do you have a job, did you write me?
Because I always have something interesting for you. How do you feel about safaris?
Not really, I've never been on a safari.

Would you like to? Well, it's not savannah here, no lions, sorry. But there's wild boars that would give your lion a leg up. That's what they need to be quieted down. They're getting out of hand. Wedge and his boys just left a few minutes ago to go shoot some mutants around the village. Care to join them?
I don't see why not. There's a lot of beasts, I still can't forget those boars by the "electric train".
Good for you, good thinking. It's good for the camp, and it won't be a waste for you. By the way, the rate for a sweep is 6,000 roubles. Each! So it's a good salary. Agreed?
You're still asking? Of course I do! Where to?
I texted you the coordinates on the PDA. They just got out, so I don't think they've started shooting yet.
Well, I'm gonna catch up.
All right, we got the mutants!
Already? What do you think of our local safari?
It's great. We should do it again sometime.
You're always welcome. There's always a lot of creatures around here. I don't know where they come from. All right, here's your reward. If there's any more work, I'll text you. Good luck.
Thanks Wolf! See you later!
Do you want to hang out while the clients are gone?
Sure. What's this about?
Tell me about yourself.

Uh, brother, I used to be a businessman back in the Soviet Union! I was one of those... the "goddamn speculators." I got caught up in a big deal, and I got the whole thing. He did what he was sentenced to, and made some friends among the thieves. When he got out, he started working with thieves, taking their loot. In three years I got busted again, and when I got out, it was a couple of years since the Soviets got busted. Something didn't work out for me with the new rules, I had to work on trifles for a long time, I got really poor and then suddenly the Zone came along. I came here and it was like old times, almost like old times! With my experience, it's the best place to sell here now.
I get the idea. Anything else you want to tell me?
I got it. Well, that's enough talk.
What do you think of Speech Therapist?

I'll tell you this: Speech therapist ain't got long to be an ace. My gut says Koba's gonna get him, and he's gonna get him. It's all going to happen. Pakhan's got a big nose, he's just showing off. He's got a snake, but he doesn't notice it, which is clear to half of the boys. I'm not telling you this so that you'll get angry left and right: I've shown you trust, so that you can trust me too. Yeah, so if you come across anything interesting, bring it to me. I'll always be in my place with Speech Therapist or Kobe.
Tell me about the junkyard.

The boys there, in that dump, weren't too happy about it. Used to be they wouldn't even go in there: rubbish, radiation... Then a couple of stalkers got lucky and found some expensive stuff. And that was it-people from all over the Zone flocked here like sore throats on an old hen. It was a total mess, but then our guys cleaned it up. The main thing is to have a strong hand and hold this scum tightly. And the Zone should be like a zone: either red trash or black thieves. That's what the boys here have approved. It's clear as day that you gotta pay for order. Guys want to eat too, so they get a cut of everything. I'm not too shabby here, but I want to get to a better place...
What's the latest news in the Zone?

I don't like that word "latest news". And you shouldn't use them so that you won't really make news that will be your last. Although we don't have such scary creatures here, but there was a story the other day... Anyway, a stalker showed up - white as a wall, hands shaking... Started confessing. Theme is this: he and a friend washed away from poltergeists, but then bam - a pack of jerks jumped out at them. So the guy gets all worked up, some crazy reflex kicked in, he slashes at his friend with a line and slices him open. He ran away at once, but the jerks jumped on the body - why would they run after meat when they had it ready? And then on the second bottle of vodka his consciousness began, and he began to howl at the whole dump: "Igor-o-ok, you gave me the only medkit then, and I'm like a bitch, like the last creature, finished you ...". Anyway, he hung himself in the night with his belt. That's what happens to people...
It's probably nothing.
It's up to you.
Anything I can do to help?
No, thank you, Savan. We're fine on our own. Although... There's a job for you. But I don't think you'll take it.
What is it, Pathogenic? Come on, spill it, I won't leave you alone. Tell me everything as it is, and I'll decide whether to take the job or not.

There's not much to tell. There's a creature that lives around here. A pseudo-dog. Sneaky bastard. When it gets dark, he comes to the camp and starts howling. It's been getting on our nerves. We tried to find his hole a couple of times, but we couldn't find anything, no sign of him or the creature, as if there was no one. But he still howled at night.
So you'd deal with him in the evening when he comes to the camp.

Ha, easy for you to say. I tell you, pseudo-dogs are sneaky, this one's elusive. And you'd have to be either an idiot or Chuck Norris to go after a mutant at night. You think you can handle it? I'll get you a helmet and an E.P.V. What's more, if you can do it, you can have the helmet for good. I'll throw in some extra cash on top of that. All right?
Come on. A night hunt, what could be better? Give me your helmet. I'll be back when I'm done.
No, thanks, I don't need any more pseudo dogs.
Well, I told you, you can't do it, you can't do it.
Only I know I can!
I got your dog, Pathogenic. You were right, it's a sneaky creature, you can't hit it. But it's all right, I'm not a dick myself. It won't howl in the night again, I guarantee it.
That's the spirit, I respect that! Here's another one from me, you deserve it. At least we'll get a good night's sleep tonight. Thanks, Sawan. Remember, you're always welcome here.
You're welcome, Pathogenic. If there's any more trouble, you know who to call.
Why did you call? You got business for me?

Yeah, I got a job just for you. We need to find a good dude to fix the boys' guns and gear. We'll pay him a trifle for each repair, as it should be, and the boys will give him respect and honor. You'll get one for your trouble, too. Will you do it?
No problem.
All right, but don't take too long.
I'm on my way.
I don't mind...
What a dickhead, he can't... Go on, then.
He's gone.
Hey Boss, I found a mechanic for the brigade, he's a cool kid and a smart one, too.
That's the deal. Now we're gonna do even better.
Well, as you say, more frizzy is more frizzy.
Listen, Dubolom, how'd you like to get into gear repair?
I don't mind. Especially, as you know with free stalkerism I'm not very good at, and I can craft so that Stepka might be jealous. But wait, Logoped is offering stalkers a job now?
Logoped doesn't care that you were a free stalker. He promises pay and the respect of the fraternity.
Then I'm in.
You got it. I'll tell Mugwumped that.
Chimera neutralized, here's the PDA.
Great! Get a new mission. We have a soldier who has deserted. Private Nikita Sergeyevich Nefedov. Apparently, he escaped to the Zone. Find out where he's hiding or make sure he's dead.
All right. It'll be easier than a chimera.
I found the deserter.
And where is he hiding?
He's dead, here's his dog tags taken off the corpse.
Well, then, good riddance to him. You and your partner can get the hell out of here.
Goodbye, I hope I never see you again.
He's in a bandit camp behind the railway tracks, posing as a stalker named Scar.
So that's how it is. I'll send a team to arrest him. You and your partner are free to go. Don't get caught again.
We'll do our best.
Look, Wolf, you're a seasoned hunter. There's a chimera I need to take out. It's keeping the soldiers alive. Can you tell me how to deal with a chimera alone?
You're not a bad hunter either, by the way. You got Leshny out, and you helped a lot with clearing the territory of mutants. So I'll tell you, hunter to hunter, there's an unorthodox way.
Unconventional? What do you mean?

You've heard of the Beastmaster? Well, he made a repellent based on the urine of a male chimera. If you smear it on unclothed parts of the body, the chimera smells a competitor and runs away. They'll run away and never come back. It's not that simple, though.
Well, it usually is. Side effects?

The fact is, the stronger the male chimera, the more special substances in the urine that signal the strength of the opponent. The female chimera will prefer to run away, the weaker male will also run away. But if you encounter a strong male, the smell of a competitor will drive him mad. Enraged. And, you know, an enraged, strong chimera male will tear you to pieces. Tear you apart like a dickens.\nBefore you can say meow.
All right, I'll take my chances. You got that repellent? How much are you asking for it?
Here you go. I'm not taking any money, don't even think about it. Consider it my thanks for saving Leshy.
Thank you, Wolf.
No, I'd rather do without the miracle repilentant. A chimera is no gift in itself, and a chimera in a rage is a certain death. No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no.
Wolf, here's the thing. Has a soldier named Nefedov been in the village?

Soldiers don't come here. We have a tense relationship with them. We don't shoot at each other, of course. But we try not to come into contact with them. They do not get close to us and we do not get close to them.
Have there been any newcomers lately named Nikita?
Some time ago, there was a rookie named Nikita. He had this weird nickname. Kasha. Nikita Kasha. But he moved to ATP a long time ago.
Thanks for the info.
Hello, Pathogenic. I have a question for you. Have you met a stalker named Kasha or Nikita? Or Nikita Kasha? Ex-military. Huh?
No, I haven't met either Kasha or Nikita. And it's not customary for stalkers to use real names.
Well, maybe you've met an ex-military man recently.
How do you define ex-military? Who's the quickest to wake up and jump at the command: Company up!?
Patogenych, don't talk to me like that. You're an experienced stalker, you've seen everything. Don't you have an eye for recognizing a soldier?

Yeah, well, there was one stalker. He was nicknamed Pogon, and he had a scar on his face, so he was definitely one of the exes. And not by his nickname, but by the way he looked at the other stalkers. Like a soldier looking at a louse. Like Lenin looked at the bourgeoisie.
And where is he now?
Fuck knows. Maybe he's dead, maybe he's gone to bandits. I haven't seen him around here for a long time.
Thanks for your help.
Speech therapist, have you seen a man called Pogon amongst your people?
Pogon? Not a cop?
No, not at all. It's just a nickname. He's got a scar on his face, and he was supposed to be here recently.
There's a little man with a scar on his face. That's what we call him, Scar.
Is he here now?
Yeah, he's around here somewhere.
I'll talk to him.
And hello to you, too. I got business for you.
What business could you possibly have with me?
Nikita, I got an assignment from the boogeyman, but I can't do it alone. I need a guide, can you help me?
Well, if it promises to be profitable... Wait, what did you call me?
I called you Nikita Nefedov, a former private in the Ukrainian army, now a wanted deserter. Kolyazin is all over the place to find you.

Damn it, my past won't let me go... Look, I can't go back anyway, but if Koljazin won't rest until he finds me, then help me. Here's my key chains, give them to him and tell him what you found on my dead body. And I'll go further north so they don't find me.
All right, come on.
Skidan, what happened to the prices?

What, what. Some smart-ass stalker messed with the military, now Kolyazin's raised the toll for shipping goods through the roadblock. And you wondered how the goods got to me? If I'd known who was shitting, I'd have ripped his head off myself. With these very hands.
So what now?
Now it's hard times for all the stalkers. Food, uniforms, ammunition and weapons have all gone up in price. And it's not profitable for me to trade here at Cordon. That's the way it is.
We have to do something.
What the stalkers will do, I don't know. If the situation with the military doesn't change, I'll move to the Dyatka checkpoint.
I see.
Patogenych, what happened to the prices?
Kolyazin has gone crazy, he's raised the price of transporting goods through the checkpoint. Now it's hard to supply, so the prices have gone up.
I see.
Antibiotic, what happened to the prices?
Kolyazin's gone rogue, he's raised the price of medical supplies through the checkpoint. So the prices went up.
I see.
Ticks, what happened to the prices?
Koljazin, the scumbag, is demanding triple-dollar fees for delivery of heaters through the barbed wire. I got to make sure I don't make a loss. Fucking business.
I see.
Hey, Cousteau, what happened to the prices?
Kolyazin's gone fucking crazy, raised the price of carrying goods through the roadblock. Now it's hard to get supplies. Which means the prices have gone up.
Got it.
You paged? What do you need me for?
I've heard about Shmyga and how he's got a good deal. But he doesn't want to do it by the book: If it's a good deal, pay a tenth of the loot to the joint.
You're suggesting I get a share out of Shmyga?
You're smart, but not just knock him out, but punish him for his arrogance and unwillingness to live up to his code.
What kind of punishment?
Properly, like a boy. Bled him with a knife, so that he'll remember and others won't be harmed. Tell him if he wants to live, let him give up his share.
Will do.
Give me Skidan's briefcase, bitch.
What? You don't want the keys to the flat where the money is? Get the fuck out of here.
What keys? Don't give me that shit. It's not your briefcase and you can't open it.
Don't worry, what's mine, I can open it.
I'm gonna shoot you now, asshole.
This is a fraternity base? You're gonna get yourself killed before you raise your gun on the right guy.
All right, I'll see you around.
Here's the scumbag's word: You didn't do what's right, you didn't pay off the spoils to the joint. That's why the gang won't fit in for you.
Bros? Well, fuck it. I'll have my own crew soon.
No, you ain't. The speech therapist said to punish you and razor-paint your cheeky face.
What? I'm gonna stab you in the face with a razor, you little punk.
Let's go.
Have mercy, don't kill me, I'll give you your share.
Well, that's a good place to start. I'll tell the Speech Therapist you said yes.
You sure you won't kill me?
Live a while.
Not so fast, bitch, you don't owe that money to Logoped, you owe it to Skidan.
But you said it was a share in the joint.
I lied! You owe all of Skidan's loot and your life. Dead men don't sweat. And secrets don't come out...
I've dealt with Shmyga.
Great, now no one can squeeze a share out of the joint. Here's a little something for your trouble.
Not bad, not bad.
You've got a nerve, you were told to cut, not to go!
I agree, I overdid it. But it was hard to resist.
Next time do as you're told, don't make a mess. What about the loot?
We don't know, Shmyga didn't have anything on him. And where the loot is, we'll never know.
Yes, you've done something wrong. Get out of my sight before I order you to get killed too.
Already gone.
Skidan, why do you have such an assortment? Vodka, food, armour, first-aid kits and shotguns?

Anything you want for your money. Heh-heh. The assortment is rich, you got that right. Everything a real stalker needs! Heh-heh. A naked rookie comes in and packs me upside down. If only I had the money. The best-selling item, of course, is vodka. Would you take a couple of bottles? It's fresh, just dropped off yesterday.

No, you don't understand. The assortment is lousy, that's what I'm saying. The shotguns and 12-gauge hunting cartridges. Any military store on the mainland would be richer. Where are the machine guns, pistols, machine guns, grenades? You're buying it up. Under the counter?
You ever been in the trade, Sawan? Run a shop in the Zone?
No, of course not.

That's what I thought. And here's my advice to you, and it's free of charge: Never, you hear me, never set up shop in the Zone. Every snot-nosed greenie will tell you every day that your range sucks. And the prices are high. Every greenhorn knows how to do business in the Zone, only Skidan doesn't, huh?\nYou think you're the first one to ask about the range? Every single day. It's probably the only reason I'm so bald. They've been all over my head about it. At first I explained to everyone that I was sitting in front of the military, and any commission from the checkpoint would go to my bunker. And I had to do everything right here, in accordance with all the laws of the country. I've got it all registered as a hunting shop, combined with a grocery shop. License, health and inspection certificates. All business. I pay taxes every month, what do you think?
Taxes? Holy shit. Bribes, maybe?

I pay bribes too, that's what I do. I suppose you thought I was doubling the price of everything and pocketing the profits for my stalker brother, too? You thought Skidan was a bloodsucker? You did, didn't you? I can barely make ends meet. My main commodity is information. And the shop... I'm good if I'm breaking even. There are months when it's a loss. Weapons I buy off stalkers for pennies, I take to the roadblock. By weight. They make it out as confiscation. And they're good - they fulfil their plan of confiscating unregistered firearms, they get stars on their shoulder straps, and extra leave. And it's not bad for me, that's why I take it for a penny, I only give it back for a little more. At least I have a good relationship with the soldiers, they don't put me under pressure. The deeper into the Zone, the farther away from the roadblocks, the wider the range. If you get to Bara, you'll have all manner of rifles and grenades, and bazookas and armour like no one here has ever seen. It's the ABCs, the basics. Now I'm not explaining it to everyone, I'm just saying fuck you!\nI'll say the same to you, Sawan. Fuck you!
Skidan, I'm sorry. I didn't know. Let's just forget about this conversation like it never happened.
Smoke, you've been on a scientific expedition for years. What do you know about the Zone? What is it? Where did it come from? Why is the Zone growing? And how will it end?

I wish I knew how it was going to end. By the way, ten years ago, I knew exactly how it was going to end. The impenetrable cordons. A belt of emptiness fifty kilometres wide. Scientists and soldiers, nobody else. A terrible ulcer on the body of the planet, blocked solidly in place.\nAnd everyone thought so, not just me. What speeches were made, what bills were introduced...! Now, you won't even remember how this steely determination suddenly turned into a mush.\nIt seems to have all started when the stalkers took the first Battery packs out of the Zone. Yeah, I think that's where it started. Especially when it was discovered what properties they had. The sores turned out to be not so much sores, and not even sores at all, but something like a treasure chest... And now nobody really knows what it is - whether it's a sores, a treasure chest, a hellish temptation, Pandora's Box, hell, the devil... They take advantage of it little by little.
Wait a minute. Haven't scientists learned anything about artefacts over the years?

Funnily enough, almost nothing. We've discovered many wonders. In some cases, we've even learned how to use these wonders to our advantage. A monkey presses a red button and gets a banana; a monkey presses a white button and gets an orange; but it doesn't know how to get bananas and oranges without buttons. And what the buttons have to do with bananas and oranges, she doesn't understand.
Take, say, artefacts. We've learned how to use them. But we still haven't managed to reconstruct any artifacts, we don't understand how they work, and it doesn't look like we'll understand it all any time soon...
I'm pretty sure that the vast majority of the time we're hammering nails with microscopes. And yet we do use something: "batteries", "bracelets", life-stimulating artifacts... various types of quasibiological masses which have revolutionized medicine...
We have new tranquilizers, new types of fertilizers, a revolution in agronomy... Let us call this group of objects useful. One could say that to a certain extent humanity has been enriched by them, though we should never forget that in our Euclidean world every stick has two ends.
Two ends? You mean the anomalies that kill? Or the Ejections?

No, that one makes more sense. Death. You don't have to go there. That's not what I mean. Every useful artefact has been more or less explained to us. It's more complicated with another group of artifacts, more complicated precisely because we have no use for them, and their properties, according to our current understanding, are wildly inexplicable. In short, the artefacts in this group are of absolutely no use to current human practice, although from a purely scientific point of view they are of fundamental importance.\nThese are answers falling out of the sky to questions we do not yet know how to ask. I won't go into details, but the existence of these objects has at once swept aside a whole field of recently flourishing theories and given rise to entirely new ideas. And then there's a third group...
Artifacts with negative properties, right?

No, no, no. All of these should fall into either group one or two. I mean objects that we know nothing about or only by hearsay, that we've never held in our hands. What the stalkers snatched from under our noses, they sold or stashed away. Things they keep silent about. Legends and semi-legends: the Pendulum, for example. Or the Death-Lamp.
Hmm... legends, then. Thank you, Smoke, for the detailed story. I won't say I've understood anything, but I'm looking at things in a new way now. I'm going to do a lot of thinking.
Wolf, there's one question that's been bugging me. It's about stalkers.
What do you want to know, Savannah?

Look, the military knows about the stalkers. They see you guys flitting around every day right in front of the roadblock. And I think they know about the other stalkers deep in the Zone, too. What's more, all the stalkers in the Zone go through military checkpoints, there are no other ways. The minefields and the worse ones around the perimeter of the Zone, there is no way in. Only through the roadblocks. I mean it looks as if the military are letting stalkers into the Zone on purpose. They are supposed to fight the stalkers and keep them out. One does not fit with the other. I'm confused.

Oh! That was quick of you, Sawan, to start asking the right questions. Other newbies take months to get to this point. You're right. The military knows about the stalkers and lets them in on purpose. That's right. They pretend, of course, that they struggle with this ugly phenomenon. But even you've realized after the second day that it's only a circus, and the soldiers aren't even trying to put a spoke in our wheel. And here's the big question: Why is that? And there's an answer. It's pretty simple. Only a stalker can find an artifact, see it, take it, and bring it into the human world.

What do you mean, only a stalker? What's there to see? You turned on the scanner-detector, came to the point where the arrow on the screen indicates, the artifact itself will jump into your hands. Not rocket science. You're not telling me, are you, Dog?

And here's the most interesting part of the Marlezonian ballet. In the early years after the Zone, there were no detectors or scanners. Stalkers simply saw artefacts as objects lying around. Or hovering above the ground. Or bouncing. Glowing. Warm. And stalkers would pick them up. They brought them to fence dealers, scientists, collectors, spies of different countries, the military. There are many who wish to get the gifts of the Zone. When a stalker picks up an artifact, it becomes visible to all the people, you understand? Stalkers are like guides, they manifest the artefact in our world, like pull them out of.... I don't know, from what. From another dimension, from another universe, from another time? Scientists have been struggling for years trying to figure it out, haven't figured a damn thing out.\nThe fact is, ordinary people don't see artifacts until they've been in the hands of stalkers. At least be equipped with scanners and detectors from head to toe - you will not see. A stalker just sees. He feels it. And no one but a stalker sees that the artifacts glow, doesn't feel that they are warm. Doesn't see how beautiful they are. To the rest of the people, they're black pieces of unknowable stuff. Cold. I've talked to a lot of ordinary people, none of them see the glow and beauty of the artefacts.
You're full of shit, Wolf! There's no such thing.

The Zone, brother. It's not the kind of miracle that happens. In short, no stalkers, no artifacts. Why do you think gangsters or mercenaries or warriors don't collect artifacts? They do not see them. They do not feel them. But 90% of people in the Zone are unable to find artifacts in principle. That's the arithmetic. Maybe even 99%, I don't know the exact numbers. Do you know why Skidan gives every newbie the same first assignment - to find an artifact? Now you know it's a test. Skidan's checking to see if you've got that stalker talent or if you're just out for a stroll. Most people don't pass the test. And you can't tell in advance who's gonna be a stalker and who isn't. It's something innate, I think. It's only when you find an artifact that you can tell.\nThe military and scientists at first tried to adapt robots to mine artefacts. They built little machines with scanners and detectors, gripping devices, lead containers, remote control, artificial intelligence, you name it. Japanese designs. Launched five, I think, of these robots at once. And all five of them were buried in anomalies for 24 hours without finding a single artifact. And they collected all kinds of rubbish in their lead bins - stones, iron. So much for artificial intelligence. That was the end of the robot experience. They spent a shitload of money on it! Sakharov, a scientist from Yantar, told me this story - he was the chief scientist in the project at the time.\nThen we decided to do military stalkers. They recruited volunteers among military contractors, and began to train them in the search for artefacts. Hired free stalkers as teachers. I was one of them. The pay was generous. But it was useless. It is good, if 1 out of 20 could find an artifact, I can consider myself lucky. You can't teach it. It's like eye colour, you're born with it. You're either a stalker or you're not. There's still a lot of military men working in the Zone, but not many of them. That's why the soldiers let everyone into the Zone, so that the Zone itself can identify the real stalkers. And when a stalker reveals himself, he won't be left without work and money. I think you understood that already. And rest assured, that both the military and the SBU are watching every true stalker closely. I think they have a dossier on you, marked as top secret. That's the way it is.
Well, Wolf, you surprised me. I'd say you surprised me. I feel like a bit of a mutant.
